greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of the sum 1/p^2 over primes p == 1 (mod 3).
comment: The prime zeta modulo function at 2 for primes of the form 3k+1, which is P_{3,2}(2) = Sum_{p in A002476} 1/p^2 = 1/7^2 + 1/13^2 + 1/19^2 + 1/31^2 + ...
link: Jean-François Alcover, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1003
R. J. Mathar, Table of Dirichlet L-series and Prime Zeta Modulo Functions for Small Moduli, arXiv:1008.2547 [math.NT]
OEIS index to entries related to the (prime) zeta function.
mathematica: (* A naive solution yielding 12 correct digits: *) s1 = s2 = 0.; Do[Switch[Mod[n, 3], 1, If[PrimeQ[n], s1 += 1/n^2], 2, If[PrimeQ[n], s2 += 1/n^2]], {n, 10^7}]; Join[{0}, RealDigits[(PrimeZetaP[2] + s1 - s2 - 1/9)/2, 10, 12][[1]]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 15 2018 *)
program: s=0; forprimestep(p=1, 1e8, 3, s+=1./p^2); s \\ For illustration: primes up to 10^N give only about 2N+2 (= 18 for N=8) correct digits.
PrimeZeta31(s)=suminf(n=0,my(t=s+2*n*s); moebius(2*n+1)*log((zeta(t)*(zetahurwitz(t,1/6)-zetahurwitz(t,5/6)))/((1+2^t)*(1+3^t)*zeta(2*t)))/(4*n+2)) \\ Inspired from Kotesovec's Mmca code
results.author: _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 01 2010
